facts.text: Writ Petition No. 270 of 1972 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 270 of 1972. Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the en- forcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Petition directed against order dated 8 July 1971 made by District Magistrate Jammu cancelling petitioner's declaration dated 23 April 1971 under section 8B of the Press Registration of Books Act 1867

anchor.surface_text: This writ petition is directed against an order dated 8 July, 1971 made by the District Magistrate, Jammu. The District Magistrate by the said order under section 8B of the Press Registration of Books Act 1867, referred to as the Act, cancelled the petitioners declaration dated 23 April, 1971.

facts.text: Petitioner is a citizen of India and permanent resident of State of Jammu Kashmir

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is a citizen of India. lie is a permanent resident of the State of Jammu Kashmir.

facts.text: Petitioner made application on 2 June 1970 to District Magistrate Jammu for permission to start weekly paper in English from Jammu

anchor.surface_text: On 2 June, 1970 he made an application to the District Magistrate, Jammu for permission to start a weekly paper in English from Jammu.

facts.text: Petitioner gave list of 11 names in order of preference, first preference Blitzkrieg

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner in accordance with the rules under the Act gave a list of 11 names in order of preference. The first preference given by the petitioner was Blitzkrieg.

facts.text: Petitioner made declaration under section 5 on 9 February 1971 giving particulars of newspaper, title, language, periodicity

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner on 9 February, 1971 made a declaration under section 5 of the Act giving particulars of the newspaper. the title of the newspaper, the language in which it was to be published as also the periodicity of the publication.

facts.text: Petitioner gave second declaration on 23 April 1971 due to changes in day of publication from Saturday to Tuesday and name of printing press

anchor.surface_text: A second declaration was given by the. petitioner on 23 April, 1971. The second declaration was necessitated because of two changes. One was as regards the, day of publication. It was shifted from Saturday to Tuesday. The other was with regard to the name of the printing press.

facts.text: District Magistrate authenticated the declaration under section 6

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate, under section 6 of the Act, authenticated the declaration made by the petitioner.

facts.text: First issue of petitioner's weekly paper published on 20 March 1971

anchor.surface_text: The first issue of the petitioners weekly paper was published on 20 March, 1971.

facts.text: Petitioner served with notice dated 7 July 1971 to show cause by 8 August 1971 why declaration dated 23 April 1971 should not be cancelled due to title Blitzkrieg similar to Blitz published from Bombay

anchor.surface_text: Some time in the month of July 1971 the petitioner was serv- ed with a numberice dated 7 July, 1971 asking him to show cause why the declaration dated 23 April, 1971 might number be cancelled inasmuch as the petitioners title of the weekly newspaper Blitzkrieg was similar to that of Blitz published from Bombay. The petitioner was asked to show cause by 8 August, 1971.

facts.text: Petitioner learned on 16 July 1971 from notice dated 13 July 1971 to Keeper of Printing Press that declaration for Blitzkrieg cancelled by order dated 8 July 1971

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner came to know on 16 July 1971 from the numberice dated 13 July, 1971 served upon the Keeper of the Printing Press where the petitioner printed the issue of his paper that the declaration of the petitioner for Blitzkrieg had been cancelled by the District Magistrate, Jammu by an order dated 8 July 1971.

facts.text: District Magistrate cancelled declaration on 8 July 1971 despite giving time till 8 August 1971 to show cause

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner alleges the District Magistrates displeasure with the petitioner. Though the District Magistrate in the numberice dated 7 July, 1971 gave the petitioner one months time till 8 August, 1971 to show cause, yet the District Magistrate cancelled the petitioners declaration on 8 July, 1971.

facts.text: District Magistrate in affidavit alleged that date 8 August 1971 in notice dated 7 July 1971 was typing error

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate in his affidavit alleged that in the numberice dated 7 July 1971 the date 8 August. 1971 was a typing error.

facts.text: District Magistrate withdrew notice by order dated 8 November 1971 and served fresh notice to show cause by 20 November 1971

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, by an order dated 8 November 1971 the numberice was withdrawn and a fresh numberice was served on the petitioner to show cause by 20 November, 1971 as to why his declaration should number be cancelled.

facts.text: Petitioner obtained rule on 2 August 1971

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner obtained a rule on 2 August, 1971.

facts.text: Respondents justify cancellation on ground that title Blitzkrieg is same as Blitz

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the respondents justify the cancellation on the ground that the title of Blitzkrieg is the same as that of Blitz.

facts.text: District Magistrate stated in affidavit that title Blitzkrieg inadvertently cleared

anchor.surface_text: In the, affidavit the District Magistrate stated that the title of Blitzkrieg had been inadvertently cleared in favour of the petitioner.

facts.text: Petitioner contended that Blitz and Blitzkrieg are different titles

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner companytended that Blitz and Blitzkrieg were different titles.

facts.text: Court finds cancellation wrongful, hasty, no opportunity given to petitioner

anchor.surface_text: The cancellation was wrongful. It was hasty. No opportu- nity was given to the petitioner. The explanation of a typing error with regard to the date indicates the unseemly haste with which the District Magistrate took action against the petitioner.

facts.text: Newspaper Blitz cannot be said to be recent publication or unknown

anchor.surface_text: The newspaper Blitz cannot be said to be either a recent publication or to be unknown.

facts.text: Court quashed order of District Magistrate dated 8 July 1971 cancelling declaration

anchor.surface_text: The order of the District Magistrate dated 8 July 1971 canceling the petitioners declaration is quashed.

facts.text: Court took notice of subsequent notice dated 9 November 1971 and quashed it

anchor.surface_text: We have taken numberice of the subsequent event during the pendency of this rule when the District Magistrate issued another numberice dated 9 November, 1971 asking the petitioner to show cause why the declaration should number be cancelled. That numberice dated 9 November, 1971 is also quashed.

facts.text: Petitioner alleges District Magistrate's displeasure with petitioner

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner alleges the District Magistrates displeasure with the petitioner.

facts.text: Cancellation infringes petitioner's fundamental right to carry on occupation of editor and business of publishing newspaper

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners fundamental right to carry on the occupation of editor of newspaper as well as business of publishing a newspaper is infringed by the illegal act.

facts.text: No order as to costs

anchor.surface_text: There will be numberorder as to companyts.

issues.text: Whether the District Magistrate followed the mandatory procedure under section 8B of the Act, including giving notice, opportunity to show cause, enquiry, and hearing before cancelling the declaration?

anchor.surface_text: section 8B of the Act. The Magistrate is to give a notice to the person concerned. An opportunity is to be given to show cause against the action proposed. An enquiry is to be held. An opportunity is to be given to the person concerned to being heard. If the Magistrate is thereafter satisfied that

issues.text: Whether the title 'Blitzkrieg' bears a title which is the same as, or similar to, that of any other newspaper 'Blitz' under section 8B(b)?

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the respondents justify the cancellation on the ground that the title of Blitzkrieg is the same as that of Blitz. In the, affidavit the District Magistrate stated that the title of Blitzkrieg had been inadvertently cleared in favour of the petitioner.

issues.text: Whether the cancellation order is violative of the petitioner's fundamental rights to carry on occupation, trade or business under Article 19(1)(g)?

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner challenges the validity of the order. the petitioner alleges the order to be violative of his fundamental rights to carry on occupation, trade or business. The District Magistrate in his affidavit alleged that in the notice dated 7 July 1971 the date 8 August.

issues.text: Whether the availability of appeal under section 8C precludes the writ petition under Article 32 for enforcement of fundamental rights?

anchor.surface_text: section 8C of the Act. It is also said that no fundamental right of the petitioner was infringed by the cancellation. The petitioners fundamental right to carry on the occupation of editor of newspaper as well as business of publishing a newspaper is infringed by the illegal act.

arguments.claim: Cancellation invalid as mandatory procedure under section 8B not followed: no prior notice, opportunity to show cause, enquiry or hearing

anchor.surface_text: The cancellation of the declaration is made under section 8B of the Act. The Magistrate is to give a notice to the person concerned. An opportunity is to be given to show cause against the action proposed. An enquiry is to be held.

arguments.claim: Cancellation wrongful, hasty, no opportunity given; typing error explanation shows unseemly haste

anchor.surface_text: The cancellation was wrongful. It was hasty. No opportunity was given to the petitioner. The explanation of a typing error with regard to the date indicates the unseemly haste with which the District Magistrate took action against the petitioner.

arguments.claim: Newspaper Blitz cannot be said to be recent or unknown

anchor.surface_text: The newspaper Blitz cannot be said to be either a recent publication or to be unknown.

arguments.claim: Subsequent notice dated 9 November 1971 also liable to be quashed

anchor.surface_text: We have taken notice of the subsequent event during the pendency of this rule when the District Magistrate issued another notice dated 9 November, 1971 asking the petitioner to show cause why the declaration should be cancelled. That notice dated 9 November, 1971 is also quashed.

holdings.text: That is not a ground for cancellation of declaration.

anchor.surface_text: In the, affidavit the District Magistrate stated that the title of Blitzkrieg had been inadvertently cleared in favour of the petitioner. That is number a ground for cancellation of declaration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inadvertent clearance of title by magistrate does not constitute a ground for cancellation under section 8B.

holdings.text: The newspaper Blitz cannot be said to be either a recent publication or to be unknown.

anchor.surface_text: The newspaper Blitz cannot be said to be either a recent publication or to be unknown.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judicial notice that Blitz is well-known publication, implying magistrate should have been aware.

holdings.text: Blitz and Blitzkrieg were different titles. So they are.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner companytended that Blitz and Blitzkrieg were different titles. So they are.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain textual difference between Blitz and Blitzkrieg; not same or similar under section 8B(b).

holdings.text: The cancellation was wrongful. It was hasty. No opportunity was given to the petitioner. The explanation of a typing error with regard to the date indicates the unseemly haste with which the District Magistrate took action against the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: The cancellation was wrongful. It was hasty. No opportu- nity was given to the petitioner. The explanation of a typing error with regard to the date indicates the unseemly haste with which the District Magistrate took action against the petitioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cancellation before expiry of show-cause period despite notice; violates mandatory procedure of notice, opportunity, enquiry, hearing under section 8B.

holdings.text: The petitioners fundamental right to carry on the occupation of editor of newspaper as well as business of publishing a newspaper is infringed by the illegal act.

anchor.surface_text: It is also said that numberfundamental right of the petitioner was infringed by the cancellation. The petitioners fundamental right to carry on the occupation of editor of newspaper as well as business of publishing a newspaper is infringed by the illegal act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Illegal cancellation prevents exercise of rights under Article 19(1)(g); appeal under s8C does not bar writ relief.

holdings.text: The order of the District Magistrate dated 8 July 1971 canceling the petitioners declaration is quashed.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the District Magistrate dated 8 July 1971 canceling the petitioners declaration is quashed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consequent to holdings on procedure violation and title dissimilarity.

holdings.text: That notice dated 9 November, 1971 is also quashed.

anchor.surface_text: We have taken numberice of the subsequent event during the pendency of this rule when the District Magistrate issued another numberice dated 9 November, 1971 asking the petitioner to show cause why the declaration should number be cancelled. That numberice dated 9 November, 1971 is also quashed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Subsequent notice during pendency suffers same defects as original invalid action.
